contacts.name: Tiziana Bonzon
contacts.title: Head of Country Cluster Delegation, Algeria, Morocco and Tunisia

field_reports.description:
Between 14 and 16 May 2025, severe flash floods triggered by intense rainfall and hailstorms affected at least 15 provinces across Algeria, with Djelfa, M’Sila, Laghouat, and Tiaret being the most severely impacted. The floods resulted in the deaths of 5 people, left 1 person missing, and injured over 100 individuals. Approximately 250 families have been affected by damage to their homes, and about 700 people were displaced due to the destruction of houses or unsafe living conditions.

The impact has been devastating for rural livelihoods. Over 3,000 livestock—mainly sheep and turkeys—were lost, with further losses still being counted. At least 12 farms and 60 hectares of crops were destroyed, and damage assessments are ongoing. In terms of shelter, 252 houses were damaged, including 110 in Tiaret, 80 in Djelfa, 14 in M’Sila, and 48 in Laghouat. Infrastructure has also suffered severely, with multiple roads rendered impassable and at least five bridges either collapsed or critically damaged.

Vulnerable rural and semi-rural communities have experienced major disruptions to their livelihoods, mobility, and access to essential services. Entire neighborhoods remain inundated, and vital transport links such as National Road 40 remain inaccessible. Coordination efforts are ongoing, with immediate priorities focusing on emergency shelter, relief item distribution, and psychosocial support for displaced and affected populations.

results.name: DZA: Flood - 05-2025 - Algeria
results.summary: Between 14 and 16 May 2025, widespread heavy rainfall and hailstorms triggered flash flooding across at least 15 wilayas in Algeria, severely disrupting normal life and overwhelming local infrastructure. The wilayas of Djelfa, M’Sila, Tiaret, Biskra, Médéa, Ouled Djellal, Laghouat, and Tipaza were among the hardest hit. The sudden rise in wadi water levels led to fatal accidents, including vehicle washouts and child drownings. Families were evacuated from inundated homes, livestock losses were reported in rural areas, and key roadways such as National Road 40 were rendered impassable. The affected population includes vulnerable rural households, travelers, and communities living in flood-prone zones. Some have suffered the loss of loved ones, housing damage, and disruption of livelihoods, especially in agrarian areas where livestock perished in large numbers. Ongoing search and rescue efforts continue in Biskra and other regions, while drainage, emergency shelter, and relief distribution remain priorities.

field_reports.description:
According to the announcement made by the Algerian Center for Research in Astronomy, Astrophysics, and Geophysics (CRAAG), on 16 December 2024, an earthquake of magnitude 4.9 on the Richter scale struck the Chlef province in northern Algeria. The epicenter was located approximately 3 km north of Zeboudja, a coastal area near the Mediterranean Sea, roughly 200 km west of the capital, Algiers. The tremor was felt in the surrounding regions, including parts of the Algerian capital, prompting concern among residents due to recent recurrent seismic activity in the country.

Although initial reports indicate no significant structural damage or casualties, the quake generated widespread alarm, with many residents evacuating their homes in the middle of the night. Several communities remain anxious due to possible aftershocks.

results.name: DZA: Earthquake - 12-2024 - Chlef earthquake December 2024
results.summary:
According to the announcement made by the Algerian Center for Research in Astronomy, Astrophysics, and Geophysics (CRAAG), on 16 December 2024, an earthquake of magnitude 4.9 on the Richter scale struck the Chlef province in northern Algeria. The epicenter was located approximately 3 km north of Zeboudja, a coastal area near the Mediterranean Sea, roughly 200 km west of the capital, Algiers. The tremor was felt in the surrounding regions, including parts of the Algerian capital, prompting concern among residents due to recent recurrent seismic activity in the country.

Although initial reports indicate no significant structural damage or casualties, the quake generated widespread alarm, with many residents evacuating their homes in the middle of the night. Several communities remain anxious due to possible aftershocks.

field_reports.description: Since late September 2024, southern Algeria has faced significant outbreaks of malaria and diphtheria, severely impacting the wilayas of In Guezzam and Bordj Badji Mokhtar (those new provinces were part of Tamanrasset Province). Heavy rains in September led to stagnant waters, accelerating mosquito breeding and increasing malaria cases to 536 registered cases with 40 deaths. Diphtheria cases have risen to 115 registered cases with 28 deaths, largely due to vaccination gaps and strained healthcare resources. The health system is overwhelmed by shortages of medications, equipment, and personnel, hindering effective response. All age groups are affected, but children and unvaccinated individuals are particularly vulnerable to diphtheria. Secondary effects include potential spread to additional regions, economic disruptions, inadequate sanitation infrastructure posing future health risks, educational interruptions, and increased psychosocial stress within affected communities.
field_reports.summary: DZA: Epidemic - 09-2024 - South Algeria Malaria and Diphtheria 2024

results.name: DZA: Epidemic - 09-2024 - South Algeria Malaria and Diphtheria 2024
results.summary: Since late September 2024, southern Algeria has faced significant outbreaks of malaria and diphtheria, severely impacting the wilayas of In Guezzam and Bordj Badji Mokhtar (those new provinces were part of Tamanrasset Province). Heavy rains in September led to stagnant waters, accelerating mosquito breeding and increasing malaria cases to 536 registered cases with 40 deaths. Diphtheria cases have risen to 115 registered cases with 28 deaths, largely due to vaccination gaps and strained healthcare resources. The health system is overwhelmed by shortages of medications, equipment, and personnel, hindering effective response. All age groups are affected, but children and unvaccinated individuals are particularly vulnerable to diphtheria. Secondary effects include potential spread to additional regions, economic disruptions, inadequate sanitation infrastructure posing future health risks, educational interruptions, and increased psychosocial stress within affected communities.

field_reports.description: As of September 8, 2024, severe flooding caused by a tropical disturbance has significantly impacted several provinces in southern and western Algeria, displacing approximately 2220 families, some of them from nomadic communities. The provinces of Béchar, Elbayadh, Beni Abbes, Tamanrasset, Naama, and Tindouf have experienced the most severe effects. In Béchar, where 2060 families have been displaced, roads have been cut off, 5 bridges have been destroyed, and both water and electricity infrastructures have been damaged. Rescue operations have been carried out to save and evacuate individuals trapped by rising floodwaters. In Elbayadh, 60 families have been affected, and 34 houses were damaged as floods swept through remote areas. In Beni Abbes, rising water levels cut off major roads, and there is a high risk of house damages from the overflow of the rivers at the opening of Bechar dam. Meanwhile, in Tamanrasset, 50 families from Nomads have been affected, with search and rescue operations ongoing for missing persons following heavy flooding. Tragically, the floods have claimed four lives, including three persons in Bechar and one person in Naama. The affected populations are facing immediate threats to their livelihoods and safety as authorities and humanitarian organizations, including the Algerian Red Crescent, work to manage the crisis and provide emergency relief.

results.name: DZA: Flood - 09-2024 - South Algeria Floods
results.summary: As of September 8, 2024, severe flooding caused by a tropical disturbance has significantly impacted several provinces in southern and western Algeria, displacing approximately 500 families, primarily from nomadic communities. The provinces of Béchar, Elbayadh, Beni Abbes, Tamanrasset, Tiaret, Ghardaia, and Tindouf have experienced the most severe effects. In Béchar, where 280 families have been displaced, roads have been cut off, 5 bridges have been destroyed, and both water and electricity infrastructures have been damaged. Rescue operations have been carried out to save individuals trapped by rising floodwaters. In Elbayadh, 60 families were displaced, and homes were damaged as floods swept through remote areas. In Beni Abbes, 40 families were forced to evacuate due to rising water levels that also cut off major roads. Meanwhile, in Tamanrasset, 20 families have been affected, with search and rescue operations ongoing for missing persons following heavy flooding. Additionally, in Tiaret, 50 families have been displaced, 30 families in Ghardaia, and 20 in Tindouf. Tragically, the floods have claimed four lives, including a father and his two children in Elbayadh and one person in Tamanrasset, with one individual still missing. The affected populations are facing immediate threats to their livelihoods and safety as authorities and humanitarian organizations, including the Algerian Red Crescent, work to manage the crisis and provide emergency relief.

contacts.name: Hosam Faysal
contacts.title: Regional Head of Health, Disasters, Climate & Crises (HDCC) Unit - IFRC Middle East & North Africa

field_reports.description: A tropical disturbance expected to impact southern and western Algeria. This disturbance, with the potential for heavy rainfall, flash floods, and strong winds, poses a serious threat to both urban and rural communities, particularly in high-risk provinces: Tamanrasset, Adrar, Béchar, Tindouf, Ghardaïa, Ouargla, Bordj Badji Mokhtar, Ain Salah, Timimoun, and In Guezzam. The projected impacts include widespread flooding, infrastructure damage, and displacement of local populations. In response, local authorities, in collaboration with the Algerian Red Crescent, have implemented a series of preventive measures. These include the dissemination of early warnings, coordination with local disaster response teams, and the establishment of crisis management cells. Additionally, community outreach programs have been initiated to educate residents on flood safety and preparedness, with emphasis on high-risk areas. National response teams and resources have been mobilized to ensure a rapid and effective response if the situation escalates.
field_reports.summary: DZA: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 09-2024 - Tropical Disturbance - south Algeria

field_reports.description: The recent floods that began on 27/08 in Bir El Ater, Tebessa province, and extended to the areas of El Ogla, El Malha, and Griguer on 30/08, have caused significant disruption and damage. Heavy rainfall led to extensive flooding, which resulted in the destruction of homes and infrastructure. The floods have affected a total of 60 families, with 5 fatalities, 40 injured, and 3 missing children who were later found alive. In addition to the human toll, one house was completely destroyed, and persons with disabilities lost their wheelchairs, facing additional challenges. The affected families have been displaced to temporary shelters, including schools, mosques, and neighbors’ homes, and urgent support is needed for their basic needs. Further assessments are required to fully understand the extent of the damage.

results.name: DZA: Flood - 08-2024 - Tebessa - Floods

field_reports.description:
According to ARC field reports, on August 9, 2024, wildfires erupted across various regions within the province of Tizi Ouzou, Algeria, causing extensive damage to agricultural fields, trees, and forests. The fires initially broke out around 11:00 AM in the daïra of Beni Douala and quickly spread to the neighboring daïra of Larbaa Nath Irathen (LNI). Despite initial efforts to contain the flames, the fires continued to spread, ultimately ravaging a vast number of hectares, including both agricultural lands and forests.

On the following day, August 10, 2024, the fires reignited in the same daïras around 12:15 PM, resulting in a massive propagation across the region. The material damages were substantial: several hectares of vegetation, including olive groves and various fruit trees, were destroyed. Additionally, three (03) chicken coops, housing approximately 10,000 chicks, were incinerated, and a Toyota Hilux vehicle, along with multiple homes, sustained significant damage.

results.name: DZA: Fire - 08-2024 - Tizi Ouzou - Algeria

field_reports.description:
On Thursday, the 29th of February 2024, significant flooding incidents occurred in two regions in the Wilaya of Jijel, exacerbating the already challenging situation caused by the recent heavy rainfall.

In the first region, AADL residencies, a total of 110 houses were affected. Families residing in these houses were forced to evacuate due to damages incurred, which rendered furniture, electronics, and household appliances unusable and ruined

Simultaneously, in the region of Al Ansar Daira, seven families were compelled to evacuate their homes and seek temporary shelter with relatives due to the flooding.

The added the number of families affected and evacuated reached a total of two hundred families.

field_reports.description:
According to the reports of the Algerian Red Crescent, Jijel Committee, the fires began on Wednesday, October 18, 2023 in the wilaya of Jijel, where they started from the municipality of Texana in separate fires, after which they affected 12 municipalities (Sidi Maarouf, Bordj Tahr, Milia, Salma Ben Ziada, Ziama Mansouria, El Aouana, Satara, Ouled Yahia, Shaqfa, Jana, Texana, and El Sahna). 200 people were registered, 18 injured, and 85 displaced.

The fires touched 7 stables (10,800 birds), 30 cows including 8 dairy cows, 13 sheep, 122 bee boxes and 12 rabbits.

(9092 fruit trees (olives, figs, lemons, grapes) were recorded

For burned areas, up to 8,000 hectares

field_reports.description:
On the evening of the 15th of september 2023, fires ignited in the Wilaya of Bejaia, in the cities of Tichy, Saket, Aach El Baz, Souk El thnin and Tamricht, and spread on the 16th of september to the wilaya of Jijel, in the cities of Awana, Ziama, Teksana and others, causing damages in lands, crops, forests and cattle, as well as material damages (Houses and cars), leading to the evacuation of a number of people, and finding shelter to the displaced.

Bejaia's fires were put down in the span of 24H, whereas the fires in Jijel are roaring still. The fires have affected approximately 10 families, which translates to 50 persons. 80 persons were displaced, as well as 20 people were Injured, without registering any deaths so far. In the municipality of Chefka, 600 m² of lands caught fire then were put off in the same day.

On the 16th, 1.5 hectars of forests and olive trees were damaged in El Millia, and 5000 m² of bushes and forest area caught fire, while rescuing the nearby fruitful trees and the rest of the forest.
field_reports.summary: DZA: Fire - 2023-09 - Bejaia and Jijel Fires

field_reports.description: Wildfires have been rapidly spreading across the northeastern region of Algeria since July 24th causing extensive devastation. The disaster has had a profound impact on 4000 families, with the Algerian Government reporting 34 confirmed deaths. The affected population heavily relies on crops and livestock, both of which have been severely impacted by the wildfires, resulting in further hardships for the communities. Many homes have been reduced to ashes, leaving families displaced and vulnerable. The dire situation has also affected the health of the population, as the flames and smoke have led to thousands of injuries. The magnitude of the disaster requires urgent attention and support to address the immediate needs of those affected. However, the prevailing weather conditions remain a cause for concern. With temperatures exceeding 45 degrees Celsius and wind speeds exceeding 50 km/h on the Tunisian borders, coupled with low humidity, the conditions continue to favor the expansion and intensification of the wildfires.

results.name: DZA: Fire - 2023-07 - Northeast Wildfires

field_reports.description: On 19th of March 2022, earthquake of M5.2 was reported in Northern Algeria at 9:59 am (GMT +0) – Western Mediterranean. The location 78 km NNW of Sétif, Algeria and 17 km NNE of Bejaïa. On 18th of March 2022 another earthquake of M4.3 was report at 05:48 local time, 6 km North east of El Omaria, Medea.

results.name: GDACS Orange: Algeria WF Green impact for forestfire in 23903 ha
results.summary: On 09/08/2021, a forest fire started in Algeria,  until 11/08/2021.

field_reports.description: Fires ravaged eastern Algeria overnight on Monday and throughout Tuesday, killing at least 34 people in Kabylie, the center of the disaster. The fires impacted 14 governorates in Algeria. 25 members of the People's National Army had died while rescuing over 100 people in Bejaia and Tizi Ouzou. Meteorologists said the temperature would reach 46ºC on Tuesday in country already struggling with severe water shortages. Government mobilize the People National Army and 12 fire engines were sent and mobilized more than 900 men to help stem the fires and protect people and property. Algerian RC is also coordinating with the government and supporting affected people by distribution of Household items and Food.

results.name: GDACS Orange: Algeria EQ Magnitude 6M, Depth:10km
results.summary: On 3/18/2021 12:04:07 AM, an earthquake occurred in Algeria potentially affecting 4300000 people within 100km. The earthquake had Magnitude 6M, Depth:10km.

results.name: Algeria - Chlef Floods
results.summary:
Chlef Province in Algeria experienced heavy rainfall on Saturday 06 March, causing Wadi Meknasa to flood including the area of the Oud Sly Commune, west of the city of Chlef. The floods caused severe damages to houses and infrastructures, sweeping away vehicles with its passengers, leading to the death of ten people washed away by the water flood including three children. The Algerian Red Crescent (ARC) played a crucial role in the response through its Search and Rescue network of volunteers in support to the civil defence efforts since the beginning.

On Saturday, specialized flood support teams consisting of 300 civil protection personnel specialized in search and rescue were sent under the rubble, in rough places and divers teams equipped with special equipment, to find the missing, the statement added.

Algerian President Abdelaziz Taboun offered his condolences to the families of the victims and ordered the help of those affected and repairs to roads, Algerian Press Service reported.

More than 500 families have been affected by the immense floods. 280 families have left their damaged houses to seek shelter in an emergency centre set by the Ministry of Solidarity.
